smell_analysis.justification: Every page labeled as a diagram (use-case, class, state, activity, or database) contains visible elements such as classes, tables, states, use cases, or actions; no page appears to show only an empty frame or title without content.

The only clear use case diagram, 'Kaupade halduse funktsionaalne allsüsteem', shows multiple actors around the system boundary and all listed use cases are placed inside the system with connector lines indicated in the diagram; the text extraction does not clearly reveal any use case oval that is completely unassociated with all actors, so no explicit violation can be confirmed.

In the use case diagram 'Kaupade halduse funktsionaalne allsüsteem', the use case names (e.g., 'Registreeri kaup', 'Lõpeta kaup', 'Unusta kaup', 'Vaata aktiivseid kaupu', 'Vaata kõiki kaupu') describe distinct system activities rather than duplicate descriptions of the same activity for the same actor, so no pair of synonymous use cases with the same actor can be clearly identified.

The package diagram 'Kaupade FASiga seotud pädevusalad ja registrid' shows packages such as 'Kaupade funktsionaalne allsüsteem', 'Isikute register', 'Kaupade register', 'Klassifikaatorite register', etc., all with unique primary names inside the package; no package contains multiple elements with the same primary element name.

In the transformed database diagrams (e.g., 'Klassifikaatorite register (transformed)', 'Isikute register (transformed)', 'Kaupade register (transformed)'), repeated columns across tables either represent independent attributes like 'nimetus' and 'on_aktiivne' or foreign key codes (e.g., 'brand_kood', 'kauba_kategooria_kood') that are explicitly connected by FK relationships; no pair of tables clearly stores redundant copies of the same business data without a foreign key connection.

All use case names in the diagram 'Kaupade halduse funktsionaalne allsüsteem' follow the same imperative-verb form, such as 'Tuvasta kasutaja', 'Vaata kaupade koondaruannet', 'Registreeri kaup', 'Lõpeta kaup', 'Muuda kaupa', 'Aktiveeri kaup', 'Unusta kaup', so there is no inconsistency between verb-starting and noun-starting names.

In the state diagram 'Kauba seisundidiagramm', each named state such as 'Ootel', 'Aktiivne', 'Mitteaktiivne', 'Lõpetatud' and 'Unustatud' is connected by transitions, and there is a visible path from the initial node 'Alg' through intermediate states; the diagram does not show any state that is clearly isolated with no incoming path from the initial state.

In the activity diagram 'Kauba lõpetamise tegevusdiagramm', all actions such as 'Vaata kõiki kaupu, mida saab lõpetada', 'Otsi kaupa (koodi, nime, seisundi põhjal)', 'Vali kaup' and 'Lõpeta valitud kaubad' are connected in a flow originating from the initial node and leading towards the final node; there are no actions that are clearly unreachable.

Across the class and database diagrams (e.g., 'Kontseptuaalne eskiismudel', 'Isikute register', 'Kaupade register', and all transformed register diagrams), association and FK connectors either show explicit multiplicities like '1' and '0..*' next to role names or follow standard database FK notation that implies multiplicities; no relationship line is clearly drawn as a UML-style association with multiplicity missing at both ends.

Several diagrams display 10 or more central elements: for example, the class diagram 'Klassifikaatorite register' shows at least 12 classifier classes (Klassifikaator, Riik, Töötaja_roll, Kauba_kategooria, Kauba_kategooria_tüüp, Bränd, Ekraani_resolutsioon, Diagonaal, Protsessor, Sisemälu, Värv, Kaamera); the class diagram 'Kaupade register' contains the main class Kaup plus Nutitelefon, Kauba_variant, Kauba_kategooria_omamine, multiple classifier classes and related elements exceeding 10; and the database diagram 'Klassifikaatorite register (transformed)' contains more than 10 tables such as Kauba_kategooria_tyyp, Tootaja_roll, Brand, Diagonaal, Ekraani_resolutsioon, Isiku_seisundi_liik, Kauba_kategooria, Kauba_seisundi_liik, Kliendi_seisundi_liik, Protsessor, Riik, Sisemalu, Kaamera, Tootaja_seisundi_liik and Varv.

In the class diagram 'Kaupade register', the class 'Kaup' is centrally placed and has numerous distinct relationship lines to other classes, including at least Kauba_seisundi_liik, Kauba_kategooria_omamine, Kauba_variant, Nutitelefon, Bränd, and several classifier classes (e.g., Ekraani_resolutsioon, Diagonaal, Protsessor, Sisemälu, Värv, Kaamera), resulting in more than six visible connectors from this single class on that diagram.

The textual and visual layout of the diagrams does not clearly show any pair of related elements whose distance is more than twice the average distance between elements on the same diagram; elements in large diagrams appear to be placed in relatively regular grids around central classes, so no explicit extreme spacing imbalance can be confirmed.

All use case names (e.g., 'Tuvasta kasutaja', 'Registreeri kaup', 'Muuda kaup mittaktiivseks', 'Unusta kaup') and activity actions (e.g., 'Vaata kõiki kaupu, mida saab lõpetada', 'Otsi kaupa (koodi, nime, seisundi põhjal)', 'Vali kaup', 'Lõpeta valitud kaubad') begin with active verbs, while decision node labels starting with 'Kas ...' are not actions, so there is no use case or action name that clearly fails to start with an active verb.

No class, table, attribute, or use case name in the diagrams consists of three or fewer characters; names such as 'Isik', 'Kaup', 'Kliendi_seisundi_liik', 'PK_Kaup', 'e_meil' and 'reg_aeg' are all longer than three characters, and abbreviations like 'PK' and 'FK' are part of key annotations rather than standalone model element names.

Entity classes and tables representing domain objects (e.g., 'Isik', 'Kaup', 'Nutitelefon', 'Klient', 'Tootaja') all start with uppercase letters and their names are singular; plural-style names occur only in register names such as 'Klassifikaatorite register' or 'Kaupade register', which are domain registers and are excluded by the interpretation rules.

In the database diagram 'Töötajate register (transformed)', the column '*FK Tootaja_seisundi_liik_kood: Integer = 1' in table 'Tootaja' has a name beginning with an uppercase letter 'T', which violates the rule that attribute or column names should not start with an uppercase letter; most other columns such as 'tootaja_seisundi_liik_kood' in the classifier table and 'isik_id' use lowercase, highlighting this inconsistency.

Database table names in the transformed diagrams (e.g., 'Isik', 'Kaup', 'Nutitelefon', 'Klient', 'Tootaja', 'Brand', 'Varv') are singular object names; plural wording like 'Kaupade register' appears only in the diagram titles or register package names, which are not individual entity tables per the interpretation rules.

No class, table, or attribute name uses a type-indicating prefix like 'tbl_', 'uc_', or 'strName'; key and index names such as 'PK_Kaup', 'FK_Kaup_Brand', 'pfK isik_id' and 'AK_Isik_e_mail' are constraint or index identifiers rather than domain element names, and prefixes PK_, FK_ and pfK_ are allowed by the rule.
